text: there is nothing I think in the range of
possible Western reactions that will
persuade President Putin to withdraw
from Crimea that's not going to happen I
think the focus of all our efforts
whether they are in national capitals
whether they are in the UN Security
Council or at the organization of
Security and Cooperation Europe and
organization which is often forgotten in
this kind of affair or with the EU
foreign ministers the focus has to be on
not allowing this crisis to turn into
hot war between Ukraine and Russia
because that would change things
enormous Lee and much for the worse and
so should the world community should
Ukraine just shrug your shoulders and
say okay Crimea it's lost
well Ukraine is never going to shrug its
shoulders and say Crimea is lost the
only point that I am making is that I
cannot think of any pattern of sanctions
available to the West that will persuade
Putin to get out of Crimea rightly or
wrongly it is too important to him and
to Russia's national interest as he sees
it so there's not much point on wasting
a vast amount of effort on the past what
we should be concerned about is a future
which looks increasingly dangerous now
that the Russians have issued this
ultimatum if this is confirmed to
Ukrainian forces holed up in there in
their Garrison's the Russians have a
historical tendency to overreach this
looks like Putin overreaching he already
has the Crimea in his grasp and if you
if it does come to hot war to use your
phrase what then will the response of
the international community be surely it
just cannot stand by and see Ukraine
more or less taken apart well one thing
I don't think is going to happen is that
any Western government would be prepared
to argue for a military response to the
Russians I do not see any combination of
military forces whether from the United
States or from NATO
as a whole going into Ukraine to fight
alongside Ukrainians against the Russian
army we would be then one step away from
a nuclear exchange that is not going to
happen
the only range of responses which I
think may give Putin pause for thought
from doing anything worse than what he
has done already although one can
understand why he has done it is some
range of economic measures some of them
will be self-inflicted as we've seen
what has happened to the ruble and to
the Russian stock market others could be
inflicted by the Western powers and and
I think at the core of this there has to
be a real close understanding between
the Germans the French the British and
the Americans and don't forget Britain
the United States are two guarantor of
Ukraine's independence and integrity
these four powers have to agree or what
is done next and then others will follow
you don't mention China in that do you
no I don't it well that's what you do
you think there is any possibility that
you could bring China into that
agreement with the United States France
and Germany and the United Kingdom well
to be honest with you I don't see the
utility of doing it and number two I
don't see the Chinese volunteering for a
job which they would find I think
extremely difficult and awkward and
distasteful so I think I would rule out
China from this unless they happen to
volunteer for a role which i think is
most most unlikely don't forget that
when I say that Britain and America -
the guarantor powers of the Ukraine's
integrity and independence this goes
back to the so-called Budapest
memorandum if I remember rightly of 1994
so we do have a historically we the
Brits have an in-store achill role to
play here and we we have to use a
combination of stick and mediation as a
way of ensuring that Putin doesn't go
further
either through attacking Ukrainian
Garrison's in Crimea or moving into the
eastern and russian-speaking areas of
Ukraine to the north of Crimea
